results.title: Mojo working: Jimi Hendrix 1942-1970
results.creator_credit: Gravity, Initial (GB), Screen Ventures, Christopher Mould, Alan Douglas and Mark Neale
results.brief_description: Part of the television documentary series “The Making of modern music”. Features live performance footage of Jimi Hendrix and personal commentary by various musicians, writers and critics in the music industry including Keith Le Blanc, Jaz Coleman, P.P. Arnold, Afrika Bambaata, Melanie Williams, John “Rhino” Edwards (Status Quo) and others. Songs include Purple haze, Johnny B Goode, Red house, The Wind cries Mary, Voodoo Chile, Wild thing. “Mojo working” is made up edited excerpts from original films by D.A. Pennebaker, Peter Neal, Peter Pilafian, Jean Peller/John Seay.

results.title: Moi universiteti = My universities
results.brief_description:
In the third part of Donskoi’s Gorky trilogy Alexei (Gorky) as a young man struggles to survive in the city of Kazan first as a stevedore and then as a labourer in a bakery where he cannot accept the simple fact of exploiter and exploited. Alexei experiences a crisis in his life from which he emerges with greater maturity. Also available on 16mm. Part 1 (The Childhood of Maxim Gorki) and Part 2 (My Apprenticeship) of the trilogy available on 16mm, 35mm and VHS. ‘The Gorky Trilogy’ is also available as one title on VHS.

Credits: Director, writer, Mark Donskoi ; photography, Piotr Ermolov ; music, Lev Schwartz.
Cast: N. Valbert, S. Kayukov.

results.title: Moi drug Ivan Lapshin = My friend Ivan Lapshin
results.brief_description:
The film opens in the present day, in colour, and the narrator reminisces about his experiences as a nine-year old child living in a provincial Russian town. As the film converts to black and white, the young boy tells of the flat he shared with Ivan, a police chief whose main activity in the cold winter of 1935 was to track down a notorious gang of criminals, but who also finds time to make a clumsy attempt at romance with an actress and to take care of his best friend whose wife has died. A detailed portrait of daily life in a pre-purge Soviet Union, ‘My Friend Ivan Lapshin’ is the director’s autobiographical reminiscence on his childhood, based on the stories of his father. Although the film is framed by the innocent observations of a child, through suggestion the narrative hints at the horrors that would become the norm in Stalinist Russia.

Credits: Director, Alexei Gherman ; writer, Eduard Volodarsky ; photography, Valery Fedosov ; music, Arkady Gagulashvili ; editing, L. Semenovoi.
Cast: Nina Ruslanova, Alexei Zharkov, Andrei Boltnev, Andrei Mironov, Aleksei Zharkov, Z. Adamovich.

results.title: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi: politics of oil
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Jeremy Murray-Brown
results.brief_description: Examines the rise and fall of the Shah of Iran, highlighting his position as a puppet in the hands of the great powers after World War II. Shows the role played by the CIA in Iran’s internal problems; the role of the Shah’s security service in suppressing all those considered disloyal; the oil boom; the promotion of Western values; the fortune amassed by the Shah’s family while the majority of the Iranians remained poor; and the revolt against the Shah led by the Ayatollah Khomeini. Narrated by Henry Fonda Suitable for upper secondary level
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Jeremy Murray-Brown

results.title: Mohamed Ali's happy day feast
results.creator_credit: Catherine Dyson, Little universe and Nicky Tyndale-Biscoe
results.brief_description: This poignant short feature follows the story of a young Somali refugee couple who start a new life in Melbourne. It traces their initial ups and downs, and their ultimate triumph in establishing a successful cafe, reuniting their family and becoming an integral part of the local community. Nominated for a Best Documentary prize at the 1999 AFI awards.

results.title: Mogambo
results.creator_credit: Sam Zimbalist, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and John Ford
results.brief_description: Clark Gable reprises his role as the hunter to become the hunted in this lusty remake of the 1932 classic, “Red dust”. Gable is a game hunter in Kenya who becomes involved in an explosive love triangle involving the respectable (yet also emotionally volatile) wife of a British anthropologist (played by Grace Kelly), and a rather forward Broadway show girl, Eloise “Honey Bear” Kelly (Ava Gardner). Marswell (Gable) hooks up early with Honey Bear who he meets while she’s waiting for an African steamer. She misses meeting up with a maharajah, and decides to stay with the rugged hunter instead. Enter anthropologist Donald Nordley (Donald Sinden) and his wife Linda (Grace Kelly), who harbours a secret desire for Marswell who is also instantly taken by her - much to the disappointment of Honey Bear. Nordley has enlisted the help of the professional safari guide to take them on a gorilla documenting hunt. Women are not the only things causing Marswell trouble however, as the native African wildlife and a potential native uprising throw more perils into the mix. Based upon a play by Wilson Collison.

results.title: Modulo: variations on a design
results.creator_credit: Francois Seguillon, ONF | NFB and Pierre Moretti
results.brief_description: Camera animation of designs for an automobile, shifting between the drawings and the prototype, and suggesting through camera movements something of the speed and vitality of the machine. What emerges is the portrait of a leashed thing, an object that seems to tremble with life like any greyhound. Through the camera and the non-instrumental music the film creates a feeling of exhilaration, of being inside this machine designed for speed. A film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francois Seguillon, ONF | NFB and Pierre Moretti

results.title: Modulations
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, ONF | NFB and Judith Klein
results.brief_description: A film of playful observation, without commentary, catching in a few simple animated line drawings the image people project of themselves in the way they dress or move. Different types of people - plump dowager, curvaceous dancer, kilted Scot, ancient Egyptian - all make their bid for attention, metamorphosing one from the other in surprising ways. Music by Gordon Fleming, Herbert Spanier, Michel Donato and Eric MacDonald. Camera by Pierre Provost.
